did.abstract: Primarily the letters of Hugh B. Martin, of Memphis, Tenn., to his cousin William B. Gordon, in Columbia, Tenn., describing his love affairs in detail; his progress while studying law; his experience with conditions practicing law in Richmond, Louisiana; his repentence and conversion to Christianity in 1861; and, briefly, politics and the effects of the Civil War and reconstruction. Other letters are from Gordon's cousin Julia while she was a student at the Young Ladies Model School in Somerville, Tenn.; one to Mary G. LeConte from her mother describing the Federal regime and the behavior of African Americans in Macon, Georgia; and a letter concerning a Whig mass meeting.
